cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning fromSuakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidab, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah Lat call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE SUB-TARGET MACHINE
div.p: Ever since the South African War the ininds of the intelligent world have beOn impressed by the necessity of riflo shooting becoming part of our national training. Lord Roberts' views on the subject are too well known to be repeated ; it is mainly owing to him that a training in the use of the rifle is now an important branch in every public school curriculum. In fact there is every hope in tho future that shooting competitions may hold as high a place in the public favour as these great national games which attract the attention of the world at large and fill our papers with the prowess of our "muddied oafs and flannelled fools" and their compeors. Rifle clubs are now to be found iiy most towns and villages of any size, but the chief reason against their becoming popular heretofore has been the cost of making the galleries and the price of the ammunition. The instruction, too, has been difficult to reduce to an exact science, and defective eyesight and faults of sighting have been found hard to counteract.

The minds of many clever men have been at work to divise some means whereby to solve these difficulties; and an American machine is now on the market which has been ladopted with great success by the American

Army and Navy, and is now in high favour among our own English sailors and soldiers. So well do our American cousins think of this machine that the following special order has been issued within the last few months to the Navy Department renting to it : "Gallery practice will be discontinued ox\ hoard ships in commission on the receipt on board of the sub-target rifle machine now being supplied. Practice with the sub-target rifle machine will be held in lieu of the gallery practice prescribed in "The Landing Force and Small Arms Instructions, 1905," and the qualification entry "B" on enlistment for the records will depend on the score made with the sub-target rifle machine, precisely as if the firing were done at gallery practice. It is not intended to restrict the practice at the sub target rifle machine to that necessary to qualify for the entry "B" on enlistment records, and as much time as is consistent with the general duty of the*crews should be devoted to this practice,as a means of promoting efficiency in the use of small arms." Since the subtarget machine has been shown in England within the last two years it has been adopted by nearly all the English regiments and by every one of the public schools. The Navy also is making use of it, and doubtless ere long it will be found in every shooting gallery that can afford the initial cost of £50.

Without embarking upon a technical and detailed account of this machine, a few words on its Workings may prove of interest to the general reader. Any rifle of any ordinary make or size can be fitted to the apparatus which attaches it to the machine and its weight and direction still remain absolutely in the hands of the user. Instead of a long and bulletproof gallery being necessary all that is required is a clear space of 20 yards at the end of which objective targets are placed varying in size to correspond to the distance they represent. No cartridges or ammunition are necessary, thus doing away with a great source of expense, though blank cartridges may he used at times to accustom the novice to tho sound. By attaching the rifle to the apparatus, whore it can be used in any of the three ifesitions, standing, sitting or prone, it is placed in connection with a delicately adjusted pointer alongside of it, which exactly follows the motions of the riflo and transmits the effect of the shot upon a small subtarget placed before This pointer works in such exact unison • with the rifle that it is an easy matter to judge from its movements the aim that has been taken and tho reasons of its failure or success. By fixing the pointer straight on the bull of the subtarget the rifle is also locked at the same position on the objective target, and this adjustment has been found very useful in correcting cases of bad shooting following from astigmatism or otherwise defective eyesight. Another delicate adjustment can be used to remedy the effect of windage, laterial adjustment levers deflecting the apparatus from its normal direction as required, and this addition lias been proved marvellously correct and effective. The subtarget machine has won tho pproval of the highest military authorities at home ; and lias already been adopted with ;roat success at Malta and other foreign stations. Colonel Maxse, C.B., D.S.O., of the Coldstream Guards, has written a full and comprehensive account of it in the "National Review" of last October ; and there is every expectation of its being taken into general use by Indian and colonial troops in the near future.

div.head: Khedival Club.
div.p: The Khedivial Club at Cairo has decided to move into Adly Pasha Yeghen's building at the Rond Point, Kasr-el-Nil.

div.head: Departure of Stosch.
div.p: The German training ship Stosch left Alexandria this morning for Naples. The train­ing ship Charlotte is, also expected here shortly.

div.head: Abbassieh Hospital.
div.p: The military hospital at Abbassieh is now complete, and the War Office has ordered some delegatee to take over the building from the contractors.

div.head: Ramleh Markaz.
div.p: According to an arrete of the Ministry of the Interior, Ramleh kism is about to be trans formed into a markaz, which will remain under the administration of the Gouvernorat of Alex­andria.

div.head: Sale of Work.
div.p: We would remind our readers of the sale of work to be held in the Scotch High School, in the Missala quarter, to morrow, at 3 p.m. Mrs. Lang Anderson has kindly consented to open the sale.

div.head: Carrison Church.
div.p: The services at the Garrison Church of St George, Mustapha Pasha, will be as usual or Sunday, viz., Holy Communion 7.30 ; parade service, with band and organ, at 11 ; evensong and sermon, 6.30.

div.head: The Brindisi Mall.
div.p: The mail for Europe, via Port Said and Brindisi, will close at the G. P. O., Alexandria, at 3.10 p.m. on Sunday. Letters intended to reach England by Christmas should be for­warded by this mail.

div.head: Drowning Accident
div.p: A British subject, Mr. Edouard Hediel by name, who was engaged in superintending repair works on Ghizeh Bridge, fell into, the Nile on Wednesday afternoon, and was drowned. The corpse was afterwards recovered, and taken to the German Hospital.

div.head: Thefts at a Ministry.
div.p: A number of articles, such as ledgers and office furniture, have disappeared from the Ministry of Finance, Cairo, where a large number of workmen are engaged in carrying out repairs. Eleven of these have been ar rested, and were yesterday examined by the moawin of the quarter.

div.head: Murder near Ibrahimieh.
div.p: A native workman was found dead in a new building near Ibrabimieh, on Wednesday. The post-mortem examination held on the body showed that death was the result of a heavy blow causing a fracture of the skull. Seven native workmen, suspected of the warder, have been arrested.

div.head: Anathema.
div.p: 'The Bible Society's agent at Bagdad reports that in the last consignment of English Bibles which he received there, all the maps had been torn out which referred in any way to Armenia. The dragoman of the British Con­sulate at Bagdad explained that the name of Amenia on a map is forbidden in Turkey.

div.head: An Attempted Suicide.
div.p: An official of the Khedive's Daira Khassa, Ibrahim Effendi Nrguib, tried to commit suicide last Wednesday. He declares he was induced to try to make away with himself owing to lack of money and the persecution be endured at the hands of his fellow- employes. He out open the veins of his arm with a rezor and lost a quantity of blood before the doctor arrived.

div.head: A Chapter of Accidents.
div.p: A native workman fall from a building in course of construction at Bulkeley yesterday, and was killed on the spot. Another native work­man fell from a building in rue d'Allemagne, and sustained concussion of the brain from which he died shortly after his arrival at the Government Hospital. A native was run over by a train near Hadra prison, and had his right leg and left foot amputated. He was taken to hospital in a precarious condition. North Corman Lloyd.

The express mail steamer Hohenzollern (7,000 tons) Captain A. Gerdes, which arrives in our port on Monday morning next 17th inst, will leave again on Tuesday, 18th inst., at 3 p.m. for Naples and Genoa (arriving on Sunday, 23rd inst) instead of Marseilles. The next departure will take place by the S.S. Schleswig, on Wednesday, 2nd January, at 3 p.m., for Naples and Marseilles, and the weekly service between Alexandria and these two ports will be maintained daring the first half of 1907. For particulars apply to the agents, Messrs. Wm. H. Muller & Co., 16 Sesostris street.

div.head: A Child Hostage.
div.p: A curious act of roguery was committed in Cairo the other day. An elegantly dad Effendi entered a bootmaker's shop in the Abdeen quarter accompanied by a girl of four years of age. He selected three pairs of boots, bat pretending that he did not know whether his parents would approve of his choice, he said he would first show thorn the goods. He accordingly went away, leaving the child behind. Needless to pay, he has not since returned to the establishment. The in­nocent hostage was afterwards restored to a distracted father at the caracol, whither the duped bootmaker had taken the child.

div.head: The Evidence
div.p: We must go by the evidence. Those who would be inclined to doubt cannot deny the remarkable results obtained every day, such results as are obtained by the Berlitz Schools— Cairn, l Sharia Kamel; Alexandria, 12, rue Rosette. The practical excellence of the Berlitz method is irretutably proved by the numerous testimonials from the highest personages in Egypt. native and European

div.head:
EGYPTIAN CAPITULATIONS.
QUESTION IN PARLIAMENT.
div.p: In the House of Commons recently, Mr.

J. M. Robertson said : I beg to ask the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether further action has been taken by the Egyptian Government in sequence to the circular which, as Lord Cromer states in his Annual Report for 1905, page 2, was addressed to the Powers suggesting, in anticipation of a renewal in February, 1905, of the functions of the Mixed Tribunals in Egypt, certain reforms in the working of the Egyptian capitulations ; and whether he will lay upon the table of the House -copies of the replies received to that circular, and other it formation showing the present state of the negotiations.

Sir Edward Grey: The circular to which the hon. member alludes, invited the Powers to take part in an International Commission to consider the question of making certain changes in the law and procedure of the Mixed Coarts. The assent of all the Powers having been obtained, the Commission commenced their deliberations, with the result that in March last, five draft laws applicable to foreigners, which had been drawn up by the Commission, were submitted to His Majesty's Government for their approval. His Majesty's Government notified their approval to the Government of Egypt in April, but I have not yet been informed whether the approval of all the other Powers has been obtained. The only correspondence of which His Majesty's Government have cognisance, is that between them and the Government of Egypt, the purpose of which I have already notified above. The replies of the other Powers will doubtless be dealt with in Lord Cromer's Annual Report, which will in due course be laid before the House ; the matter does not appear to His Majesty's Government to be of sufficient urgency to warrant the immediate publication of separate papers.

div.head: NEW FRENCH MINISTER.
div.p: A Havas telegram from Marseilles states that M. Klobukowski, the new French Diplo- nsatio Agent and Consul General in Cairo, embarked at that port for Alexandria yesterday. He may therefore be expected to arrive here on Tuesday next.

div.head: THE BUDGET.
div.p: A committee, composed of Mob. Suleiman Pasha, Ali Sharawi Said Pasha, and other members of the Legislative Council are now studying the 1907 Budget. They will give their views on the same to the Council on Tuesday next.

div.head: AN EGYPTIAN BANK.
div.p: A group of native capitalists, have decided to found a bank at Cairo with a capital of £600,000 in 150,000 shares of £4 each. Of these 50000 will be allotted to the public. It is to be called the 'Banque du Caire."

div.head: BANK OF ATHENS.
div.p: A telegram from Athens states that the board of administration of the Bank of Athens has Appointed M. Jordanopoulo, who with M. Z. Maltas occupied the post of manager at Athens, as chairman. An extraordinary general meeting of share-holders will he held on January 12 next for the election ot a general manager.

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT, LTD
div.p: Information has been received by the last mail from England that the second ordinary general meeting of the shareholders of the Corporation is to he held in London on Decem- ber 15. The report of the directors and the balance-sheet to September 30 has been published, and copies will shortly be available for distribution to shareholders in Egypt.

div.head: ST. MARK'S BUILDINGS.
div.p: Mr. Goo. B. Alderson writes : -St. Mark's Company evidently treat my veiled threat with scorn. If any interested parties will com- municate with me showing I have their moral support I will give my solicitor instructions.

div.head: GOLD FOR ABYSSINIA.
div.p: £20,000 LEAVING CAIRO.
We understand that £20,000 in gold will shortly be despatched to Abyssinia from Cairo for account of the Bank of Abyssinia.
This, we believe, will be the first time that a large quantity of gold coin has been imported into Abyssinia, where the Maria Theresa dollar has up to nOW been supreme.

It is hoped that Abyssinia may eventually adopt a gold standard. In loot, its adoption would seem to be necessary if the country is to make any but the slowest economic progress. If the gold standard is adopted there is every reason to expect that the English sovereign will become the current standard coin of the country.

Application has been made to the Committee of the London Stock Exchange to allow the following security to be quoted in the Official List : Bank of Abyssinia-Bearer Warrants for 100,000 Shares of £5 each £1 5s. paid, Nos. 1 to 100,000

div.head: THE LAND BOOM.
div.p: Offers have been received for the land on which the house of the late M. Felix Snares stands at Rond Point Suares, Cairo, at L.E. 80 per square metre. This same plot changed hands somewhere about September last at L.E. 65 per square metre.

Land at Khartoum is going up in price by leaps and bounds just as much as it has been doing in Egypt proper. A good instance is the island between Omdurman and Khartoum Points. At the end of last year the rate ruling then was L.E. 15 per feddan. During the summer it advanced to L.E. 150 per feddan, and the last transaction reported quotes the price at L.E. 450.

div.head: BENI SOUEF INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL
div.p: The subscribers to the proposed industrial school at Beni Souef held a meeting on Wednesday under the presidency of the Moudir. Major Hall, of the Ministry of the Interior, was present.

It was stated that LE. 10,000 had already been subscribed, and 101 feddans had been presented for the same object. This land had been formed into a Wakf, the revenues of which would be assigned to the school. More funds being requited, a subscription was opened on the spot. Thirty notables undertook to pay a sum of LE. 900 for the first three years of the foundation of the school. It was decided to elect delegates under the presidency of the Moudir to submit the project to the Khedive.

div.head: THE BRAEMAR CASTLE.
div.p: The Braemar Castle (Captain Henderson), which arrived at Alexandria yesterday from Southampton, Gibraltar and Malta, disem barked detachments of the 6th Inniskilling Dragoons and details of the K.O.S.B.'s for Cairo, besides Borne of the 60th Rifles for Khartoum and two officers of the Royal Dublin Fusiliers for Alexandria, Lieutenants Wilson and De la Poer Beresford.
The Braemar Castle sailed to day with the Lancashire Fusiliers for Malta. She had a good passage out from England, and there was very little sickness among the troops on board.

div.head: CAIRO PHARMACY BURGLED.
div.p: Another burglary was perpetrated in Cairo on Wednesday night, when Norton's well-known pharmacy in Kasr el-Nil was broken into and the till rifled. The doors were looked and the shatters fastened as unusual at about 11 o'clock that evening, and it was not until the employes arrived on the scene at 7 next morning that anything was found to be wrong. No untoward sounds had been heard daring the night by the inmates of the rooms over the shop, and to far there has been no clue to lead to the identification of the culprits. The till had been prised open and its contents carried off, but nothing elee in the shop had been touched.

div.head: TARDRESSING CAIRO STREETS.
div.p: A home contemporary remarks The Cairo Tanzim service is top dressing the streets with tar. This is a great improvement, in view of the many motor oars, so far as laying the dost, and would be more effectual were the roads better constructed. However, the Govern-ment do not seem inclined to lay out much money in road construction, as they have apparently set their hearts on carrying out a hugs system of town drainage. This scheme, seeing that for 2,000 years at least Cairo has not possessed any drainage system, is not likely to come into being for the next few years. Meanwhile, the good old BUD continues to act efficiently as Nature's scavenger, and keeps the place sweet and clean.

div.p: Facing the Sea on the New Quay of Alexandria

div.head:
SUDAN NEWS
PROTECTION OF FORESTS
div.p: The Sudan Government has issued a pro clamation for the protection of forests which are called Government Protected Forests, and are situated in the Province of Sennar, on the banks of the Blue Nile.

Whosoever (1) trespasses or pastures cattle to trespass ; (2) causes any damage by negli- gence in felling trees of any description or dragging any timber ; (3) strips off the bark or leaves from or otherwise damages any tree ; (4) hunts, shoots, fishes, or sets traps or snares, shall be punished with a fine which may extend to L.E. 10, or when the damage resulting from the offence amounts to more than L.E. 10, to double the amount of such damage.
If fire is put in those forests the fine may be L.E. 20 and the imprisonment six months.

div.head: SUDAN HARBOURS AND LIGHTS.
div.p: The Sudan Government has issued an Ordinance for Harbours and Lights in the Sudan ports. The Board will be composed of : the Director of Steamers and Boats, the Governor of the Red Sea Province, the Controller of Harbours and Lights, and such other person or persons, if any, as the Governor General may from time to time appoint.

The following shall be harbours for the pur-poses of this OrdinaDC3 : Port Sudan, Suakin, and any other port or place which may be proclaimed in future ; and the Harbour Master or Acting Harbour Master has the fall power io any harbour in which he may be present, and his orders must invariably be obeyed. Should any person fail to obey he shall be liable to be punished with imprisonment for a term not exceeding one month or with a fine not exceeding L.E. 5.

div.head: OMDURMAN LANDS AND BUILDINGS.
div.p: All land and building sites, whether occupied or not, within the town of Omdurman are the property of the Sudan Government, and have ever since the reoccupation of the Country been so considered. Sir Reginald Wingate Pasha, Governor General, has been willing to make certain grants and give certain benefits to the old inhabitants of Omdur- man and the present occupiers. For that purpose he has ordered a commission to consider the above question and do all that is best for the welfare of the inhabitants.

div.head: APPOINTMENTS.
div.p: Messrs. A. M. Aequith, T. A. Leach, C. A. Ball, K. Cornwallis, J. R. Hetherington, C.C. Soott-Monorieff, J. D. Craig, and R. B. Sandford hive been appointed deputy inspectors iu the Sudan Government. Mr. Jeffes, G.E., has been appointed Deputy Assistant Director, Agrionltare and Landa Department, Sudan Government Mr. A..G. Bisset has been appointed deputy inspector of the Woods and Forests De-partment. Mr. H. A. Pollock Hodsall has been appointed deputy inspector, Agricultural and Linds Department. Mr. H. Wynne has been appointed super-intendent of the Posts and Telegraphs De-partment. Mr.H. B.Meade has been appointed assistant veterinary surgeoD, Veterinary Department

div.head: NATIONAL HOTEL AND RESIDENCES.
div.p: We mentioned in a recent issue that the above company is to form part of a new local Hotel Combine that will include also the Hotel-Casino of Ain Sofar, in the Lebanon, which is likewise the property of the same company. The latter property was purchased last year for £16,000 and consists of some 80,000 pics of land besides the hotel-casino. For the land alone an offer of purchase from a group in Egypt at ten shillings per pic has just been made to the directors, and this represeats £40,000 for the total area. The hotel at Ain Sofar contains one hundred rooms and a handsomely appointed casino, similar to those at Vichy and Dieppe, which are much frequented daring the season by the large number of visitors that spend the summer months in the delightful climate of the Lebanon.

The National Hotel, which is situated in one of the finest and most fashionable quarters of Cairo, cost £153,000 for site and buildings, bat the property at present values is worth quite doable this sum. The hotel and adjoining residences contain 200 rooms but when the new wing now under construction is completed there will be no less than 600 rooms. A new dining hall to accommodate 350 guests was added dating the past summer and many other improvements were also carried out.

There are already a large number of visitors at the hotel, much greater than at the same period of last year, and the receipts for November last were P.T. 84,552, compared with P.T. 28, 273 during the corresponding month of last year. The shares of the company at their present quotation of LE 4 1/4 are, we think, much below their intrinsic value and should prove a good investment at that price,

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Florio-Rubattino S.S Orione, which was due at Alexandria on Sunday next, has beeu detained at Naples owing to the general strike of ships' crews.
The Messigeries Maritimes SS. Portugal arrived at Marseilies from Alexandria yesterday morning.

div.head: THE NATIVE PRESS.
div.p: MUSTAPHA KAMEL'S MISSION.

"Al Watan" says : Many of us are genuinely perplexed on the subject of Mustapha Pasha Kamel's friend, Mohamed Bey Ferid. They demand the motive of his journey to London with his friend the Pasha in terribly cold weather, when all the English who can are literally flying to the Nile. Some say that Ferid Bey has become the Yawer (aide-de camp) of the Pasha and must therefore attend him at all times and seasons ; others that he has been delegated by the famous "society" to control the expenditure of its manager ! Others again assert that Fend Bey is somewhat sceptical as to the arrangement said to have been concluded between the Pasha and the British Parliamentarians to chase the redcoats and the British Agent from Egypt, and has gone—to see with his 'own eyes and hear with his own ears. Doubtless he will write his signature on the "agreement" between the owner of "Al Lewa" and the Irishman Dillon. Allah alone knows the seen and the unseen !
It is rumoured in Cairo that Mustapha Pasha Kamel has decided to go no farther than Paris on his mission. We wonder if this decision is due to a fear not only of atmospheric but popular coldness !

div.head: THE DECORATIONS SCANDAL
div.p: "Al Moayad" remarks : The question of distinctions and grades in Egypt is the same as in Russia, Spain, Italy, Turkey, and Persia. H H. the Khedive confers certain grades and decorations "directly," while he confers others "indireotly"on a great number of functionaries, notables, omdehs, etc. Merit apart, it is im-possible that some of these recipients of grades and distinctions should escape from the calumnies and slanders of persons, who, rightly or wrongly, hold that they have been unjustly deprived of the honours that are their due. Bat the "Times" correspondent has probably never dreamt of enquiring of this class, to enlighten us as to who are the real vendors, buyers, and brokers of grades

H.H. the Khedive may return to Constan-tinople all the distinctions of which he has the right to dispose to his countrymen, without shaking his legal position. Bat every diminution of his powers by the English only increases his influence with the nation, and it is certain that autonomy and occupation are irreconcilable.

To this "Al Watan" replies : We were the first to dementi the accusation against the Khedive .... bat we mast admit that in the case of many distinctions their recipients cannot really be said to merit them. Consequently we should have wished to see our confreres in concert inviting the Government to take such measures as will prevent a recurrence of such—mistakes.

div.head: NATIONAL UNIVERSITY.
div.p: The committee of the proposed National University met yesterday afternoon at the . High Schools Students Club, Cairo, under the presidency of Kassim Bey Amin. It was decided . to deposit the funds collected for the scheme with the German Orient Bank, which would allow 6 % interest on the money.

The committee will appeal to the notables of Egypt to show their generosity in subscribing for the scheme on Thursday next. Sub-com- mittees for the provinces will be formed from among those who answer the appeal.

div.head: CANADA AND EGYPTIAN IRRIGATION.
div.p: M. Dupont in his latest circular draws an interesting comparison between the irrigation works of Egypt, by which (remarks the "Financier) vast tracts of land have been reclaimed. and the similar works now in progress in the Canadian North West, where mile upon mile of prairie is being turned into valuable agricultural land by the irrigation companies. Irrigation, as the French banker points out, has this great advantage, that it ensures regular crops. It supplements an insufficient or un- evenly distributed rail fall and enables the farmer to increase or diminish the humidity of the soil at will, thus counteracting the caprices of the seasons. To a large extent the introduction of irrigation into Canada was due to the American farmers who crossed the border and who know of its advantages from practical experience.

div.head: THE STUDY OF ORIENTAL LANGUAGES
div.p: The Departmental Committee which has been promised by the Prime Minister for the purpose of inquiring into the possibility of establishing a school in London for the teaching of Oriental languages will, the "Tribune" understands, be appointed with out delay. Among those mentioned for Appointment on the Committee are Prof. Charles Wells (Oriental translator at the Foreign Office), Sir Robert Douglas (Professor of Chinese at King's College), Mr. Byron Brenan, C.M.G. (late British Consol at Shanghai, and formerly student- interpreter in China), Sir J. H. Kennaway, M. P. (representing the missionary societies), and Mr. J. D. Rees, M. P., who has had a wide experience as an official translator, both in India and Russia.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: It is stated on good authority that Queen Ena's brother, Prince Leopold of Battenberg, who spent some time in Egypt last winter, will go to the Canary Islands this winter where he will stay for several mouths for the benefit of his health. King Alfonso, on his return from his recent visit to the Archipelago, brought back such good accounts of the wonderful climate of the Canaries that his Majesty recommended Princess Henry of Battenberg to send her son there. He will stay at Santa Cruz, on the south side of the island of Teneriffe, where the weather conditions are absolutely ideal.
Sir Edward Elgar, who has been indisposed, has been abused to try a sea trip, and will leave England at the end of December with Lady Elgar on the Orient Pacific liner Oroutes tor Egypt.
Count Carlo Rasponi, Italian Deputy, left for Europe yesterday by the Italian steamer.

Capt. Owen, Sudan Agent and Director of Intelligence, accomplished by Naoum Bey Shou keir, yesterday visited Damietta prison, where he inspected the Dervish prisoners. He return— ed to Cairo ip the evening.
Baron Purie and Baron Jean de Crawhey, two well known members of the Belgian Motor Car Club, have decided to traverse the Sahara in motors specially constructed for desert travel.

Mr. C. T. Holland, after having so success-fully launched the United Egyptian Lands, Limited, is leaving Alexandria to-morrow by the Austrian Lloyd steamer for Trieste and London. He expects to return to Egypt towards the end of next month.
The Rev. F.B.N. Norman-Lee, Chaplain to the Forces, and Mrs. Norman-Lee, arrived yesterday by the transport Braemar Castle, and are staying at the Miramare Hotel.
M. Henry de Vries is leaving Port Said for London by the P. & O. S.S. Macedonia on Monday next.
Mr. Henderson has been appointed inspector of works attached to the General Inspectorate of Upper Egypt

div.head:
POPE AND FRANCE
ITALIANS RESENT AFFRONT
69 CHURCHES PROSECUTED

div.p: The provincial clergy do not recognise the competence of the laymen and are leaving their residences and seminaries, They are pre-pared to conduct services to-day without giving the notice required by law.
(Reuter)

Monsignor Montagnini arrived and drove straight to the Vatican. The Papal organs vehemently resent the affront to the Pope's representative. The French Government, they say, is grossly mistaken if it thinks it can intimidate the clergy or break down dutiful legitimate resistance.
(Reuter)

The usual masses were held this morning. The congregations were scanty. Proceedings were afterwards instituted against 69 churches. The Anglo-American Catholic Church and one other complied with the law. Yesterday's collective application was unauthorised.
(Reuter)
Proces-verbaux have been drawn up against the curates of Paris and the departments who have refused to give notice.
(Havas)

div.head:
EDUCATION BILL
AMENDMENTS REJECTED EN BLOC

div.p: HOUSE OP COMMONS.—The House decided to reject the Lords' amendments to the Education Bill en bloc by 416 votes to 107.
(Reuter)
HOUSE OP COMMONS.—Mr. Birrell said that the Government was most anxious to save the Education Bill. He hoped the Lords would realise the necessity for doing so.
Mr. Balfour replied that if the Bill was lost the Government's procedure would be responsible for it.
Mr. Asquith said that if the solution of the question, embittered by strife, was not attained Mr. Balfour would be responsible for it.
(Reuter)

The Reichstag rejected by 178 votes to 168 the supplementary estimates of 30,000,000 marks, for the repression of the rebellion in South West Africa. Prince von Bulow immediately read an Imperial message dissolving the Reichstag. Before the vote was taken the Premier strongly appealed to the patriotism of the House.
(Reuter)
The Reichstag has been dissolved, on its refusal to vote the supplementary estimates for Africa.
(Havas)

Sir E. Grey stated that the United States had intimated her desire to co operate in the realization of reforms in the Congo Free State. The announcement was most welcome. A farther statement Is unnecessary pending Belgium's decision.
(Reuter)
The agreement regarding Abyssinian railways has been signed here, are well as the convention regulating the importation of arms from French, British, and Italian East Africa.
(Reuter)
The Shah is much worse. He is visited by spells of unconsciousness.
(Reuter)
Mr. Muller has been elected President of the Federal Council.
(Havas)

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT
div.p: AGRICULTURAL DEVELOPMENT

The only oasis, of the four included in the company's concession, where the work of development has begun, is Khargeh, and considering the difficulties of transport the work that has already been achieved is very creditable. The concession was signed on July 3rd, 1903. Two expeditions were despatched during the following autumn and the company was incorporated on July 29th, 1904. The actual work of development began in the spring of the following year and drilling commenced on March 3rd, 1905, at El Der, where a plentiful supply of water was found. Shortly after the commencement of drilling, water was struck at a depth of 25 feet, rising to within 15 feet of the surface. On continuing, several successive beds containing water were passed through, and at a depth of 382 feet 6 inches a true artesian flow was obtained, the bore discharging about 100 gallons per minute, 2 feet 6 inches above the general surface of the surrounding land. This water was of exceptionally good quality, the temperature being about 82 1/2 F.

Since then the Corporation has made con­siderable progress in tapping this inexhaustible supply, and the following boring rigs were working last month. The figures show a good record of the progress of the wells up to the 13th ulto.

Practical agriculture began with a plot of rice grown in the four months after the first drilling operations and in October Mr. Milne, the well-known agricultural specialist of Aberdeen University, was appointed Director of the Agricultural Department of the Oasis. He began with a plot at El Der and at the same time Mr. Beadnell, the Oases Manager, commenced at the Machina Estate, which is the present headquarters of the Corporation in the oasis. Wheat and barley were put in. When the sowing was finished at the end of last month over 150 feddans will be under cultivation. Water is so abundant that, provided hands and rigs are forthcoming there is practically no limit to what can be done. The only two sites that have yet been touched are at Der and Machina ; at the former 500 feddans and at the latter 5,000 feddans, are cultivable. The Corporation is entitled to take up lands at the rate of 20,000 feddans a year, and when the railway is finished, this can easily be done in the early years of the concession. The staple crops are rice, wheat, barley, and dates. There are small quantities of dhurra beladi, onions, and lucerne grown. It may safely be said that any crop grown in the Nile Valley can be also grown in Khargeh. The cotton plants are healthy, the fibre is good ; and all the experiments prove that cotton will grow there. The Ashraouni variety was by far the best yield, and this will very probably be the staple type of cotton together with the Afifi. Tomatoes, melons and other vegetables grow well. The agricultural conditions at Dakhleh are more favourable than at Khargeh owing to that oasis being more populated and better cultivated than Khargeh, but the latter will be just as good when it has been developed and there is probably more land to be taken up there than in Dakhleh. Both oases will be developed together, for the railway will go on to Dakhleh. On the road thither it is difficult to tell where one oasis begins and the other ends as all the land is cultivable. Experiments are now being made in growing eucalyptus, sisal for rope fibre, and potatoes for winter export to London. Willows, acacias and sisaban are easily grown trees. The fruit supply in Khargeh and Dakhleh is capable of great development. Oranges flourish luxuriantly, while lemons, apricots, mulberries, bananas, figs, and olives grow in abundance. In Dakhleh the grapes and peaches are delicious. The dates are especially good, better than in the Nile Valley. Practically any fruit will grow well there. The only fruit to which careful attention has as yet been given is the date, which is the product par excellence of the Western Oases, and has been for centuries their staple export. Thousands of tons are carried every year by pack camels across the desert to the Nile Valley, where they are eagerly sought after owing to their sweetness being for more marked than the Egyptian date. When the railway is finished all this export trade will be taken over by the company. The carrying trade is now in the hands of Bedouin and a considerable portion of the trade is done by barter, the dates being exchanged for dhurra, etc. The company's packing centra is at Khargeh town. Here the dates are bought and selected and despatched thence to Cairo and London in special cases. A second quality is packed in fibre baskets and skins for native and European markets. The large quantities that are at present being sent off by caravan find a ready market. Mr Bayley is controller of the Date Export Department and has a large staff of natives under him, who have been taught to pack the dates with the necessary cleanliness. Baharieh will afford a better opportunity for developing the trade in date exports than either Khargeh or Dakhleh for that oasis is essentially the greatest date-producing centre in Egypt. In Dakhieh and Khargeh there are only seven and a half and eight palm trees per inhabitant, but in Baharieh there are about fifteen trees per inhabitant. In Baharieh and Farafra the taxation is based on the land cultivated and not, as in the two southern oases, on the water and dates, which are taxed fifteen milliemes yearly. The number of trees in Baharieh at the 1897 assessment was : apricots, 4,863, olives, 5,370 and palms 93,000, and three-fourths of the whole date production is exported. The dates are excellent and the villages of that oasis are crowded with camels and traders from the Nile Valley each November. A camel load of dates, packed in two plaited-grass bags, is bought in the oasis for 500 milliemes, and is sold in the Nile Valley for four times that sum, so that the Bedouins, to whom the trading is almost wholly confined, even allowing for difficulties of transport, make a good profit. As yet that oasis has not been touched by the Corporation, but its agricultural prospects are excellent, and although dates are the only fruit exported, olives, apricots, pomegranates, oranges, lemons and figs are grown in great number.

Of the four important manurial ingredients required by crops there are supplies of phosphates, lime, and nitrate shales. Potash, the least important of the four, which does not appear to have the importance in Egypt that it has elsewhere, has not yet been found in Khargeh.

As a rule the surface of the land is fairly level and well adapted for irrigation purposes. There are no heavy stones or other objectionable matter to be removed from the surface of the soil. There is little probability of being bothered by obnoxious salts. Not much drainage is required and what is necessary should not offer any difficulties. As to the water supply, which we have already dealt with in another article, it will suffice to say here that the underground artesian supply being practically inexhaustable the output at the surface may be almost indefinitely augmented, provided the wells are sunk in suitable localities and kept sufficiently far apart to avoid any appreciable reduction of the hydrostatic pressure.

With such facilities for irrigation and a soil specially suited for agriculture—for loam is the basis of a good soil and an alluvial lake deposit of loam is always there—it will be acknowledged that the oases of Khargeh and Dakhleh contain all the ingredients of an agricultural paradise. ,

N.B.—In the 8th line of the 3rd paragraph in our article of Wednesday, the total length of the railway line should have been given as 120 miles, not kilometres (195 kilometres). Secondly, 16 lines from the end of the article it is said that "the gradient will be 1 in 25." This is an error. The very steepest place is at Kilometre 150 (the descent into the oasis)] where the slope is 1 in 40.

div.head: AN ABNORMAL RAINFALL
div.p: Deluges of rein have fallen since Thursday, 29th ultimo. Here, in Larnaca, and in Nicosia the rail fall recorde lis quite abnormal, amount­ing in the latter town to over six inches fur the week, and similar reports are to hand from the various districts of the Island. The rivers, which for many months past have been mere dry river beds, are now in flood, and walls are being filled. This is a much needed occurrence, as the shortage of well water ba« affected the drinking supply, and in the towns there has been some recrudescence of illness. Native habits do not impose that strict care in the management of the drinking water that a proper regard for health demands, and it is therefore not surprising that when the wells get low oases of typhoid and other complaints occur. A few cases of smallpox in Nicosia are reported.

div.head: ENTERTAINMENT AT FAMAGUSTA.
div.p: On Saturday last a concert was given at Famagusta in aid of the local hospital. Ex­cellent support seems to have bean forth­coming, and we understand that the financial results have been very satisfactory. The enter- tainment was held, however, under consider­able climatic disadvantages, as "the rain descended and the floods came," and both performers and audience alike had many adventures before finally reaching the concert room ; those especially who had travelled down from Nicosia- Special arrangements bad been made for conveying the Nicosia visitors bark to the Capital the same night, but this plan could not be carried oat There was no little difficulty in getting them to Famagusta, as a portion of the railway line had been damaged by the heavy rains, and passengers had to "foot it" for a short distance at a spot about half way down the line. Every assistance, how­ever, was rendere by the railway authorities, and although the return could not be made before Monday, the unexpected week-end vi it seems to have passed off satisfactorily to all concerned, not excepting the hotel proprietors.

div.head: A NEW MAIL BOAT,
div.p: The S.S. Salamis. the newly acquired vessel of the Limassol Steamship Company, has com­merced carrying the mails, and is expected to prove a useful addition to this company's line of mail steamers.

div.head: STOCK EXPORTS TO EGYPT.
div.p: The official "Cyprus Gazette" of the 30th ulto. publishes a notice in regard to the expor­tation of stock from Cyprus, drawing attention of the fact that as, under the regulations in force in Egypt regarding the importation of animals, very severe restrictions are imposed if such arrivals are not accompanied by a certificate that they are healthy animals, the Government of Cyprus, in order to give faci­lities to exporters and to encourage trade, have scoured the services of a veterinary surgeon, who will henceforth issue certficates under certain regulations.

These provide (a) for specified notice to be given to the veterinary surgeon by intending exporters to enable him to ex imine animals previous to shipment; (b) for the elimina­tion of such animals by the veterinary-surgeon and the granting by him of a certificate to that effect: the required conditions of payment having been complied with ; and (c) that for the present snob examination will be made only at the ports of Larnaca, Limassol, Fama- gusts, and Papho.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
div.p: Kearsley and Cunningham's Weekly Report
Liverpool, December 6.

Egyptian cotton has been much more active this week, the trade buying freely ; there has also been some bought on speculation. Quota­tions are raised as follows Brown, Fair to Good Fair 3/8 per. lb. Fully Good Fair while Good and Fine are 1/4 per lb. dearer. Upper Egyptians are per lb. dearer all round. The following are the latest values, for Futures Dec. 9.55d Mar. 9.49 June 9.49 Jan. 9.49 April 9.48 July 9.49 Feb. 9.48 May 9.49 Aug. 9 48

American Futures. The market this week has experienced a sharp reaction, prices at one time being almost 30 points, below those of last, Thursday. There has been a partial recovery, and to day's closing values are some 8 points above the lowest rates touched. The decline has been quietly due to he ivy realiza­tions, and to manipulation, whilst the uncer tainty about the next Ginuers' Report, and the Bureau Crop estimate, expected about Monday or Tuesday of next week, has checked all freeh speculative disposition. The crop movements meanwhile are upon a large scale. and seem to lend some contenance to the big crop estimatcs which have been formulated ; but this movement, we believe, is much more due to the enormoos amount of cif. cotton sold forward to Great Britain and the Conti- nent, for shipment during November, December, January, etc., rather than it is any certain indication of an abnormally big yield. Most of the later estimates being received from the South are in the neighbourhood of 12 1/2 millions.

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET
div.p: The Money Market.

The important feature of the week in the money market his been the statement made to the United States Congress by Mr. Secre tary Shaw regarding his future attitude in the matter of money stringency. ''The Treasury,' he says, "now holds in its own vaults a working balance of 78,000,000 dollars, the last available dollar of which will be deposited if business transactions require it, though it become necessary to pay the current expenses of the Government with cheques on depository banks.... Treasury operations must be made subordinate to the business interests of the country."
This announcement is very gratifying, and will have an important bearing on the monetary movements in the future.

Is also satisfactory to note his statement that the United States can ill afford to disturb financial conditions in Europe, and if necessary to prevent it he would not hesitate to make deposit in national bank a on condition that the banks in turn promptly deposit an equal amount abroad. "The world throughout is enjoying an unprecedented period of prosperity and no Government operations in this country must be permitted to interfere therewith a home and abroad,' We have frequently point ed out. that it would not be to the interest of the United States to disturb the European market, and Mr. Shaw's assurance that this will not happen is very welcome at the present juncture.

The Bank statement this week shows the the provincial demands for correctly have proved rather heavier than anticipated. Thus the note circulation has expanded by £310.000 and although £344,000 in gold was receive during the week from abroad, there is a decrease in the coin and bullion of £361,000 The reserve is accordingly down £672,000 The proportion of reserve to liabilities, how ever, is practically unchanged at 44
The outside market is considerably below the Bank's terms, which are 4 1/2 to 4 1/2 per cent The Stock Markets.

This week markets have been quiet, and throughout a sagging tendency has been notice able. There has been a good undertone, but several factors have helped to check business. One of the chief of these has been the monetary situation It is generally recognised that this week's slight stringency can only be of artem - orary character, but with the approach Of next week's settlement there has been little inclined tion to deal, particularly in view of the fact that the account will be broken by the Christmas holidays.

The announcement made by Mr Shaw that he will render assistance to the banks when necessary for a time exercised a cheering influence on the markets, but they have now relapsed again into a condition of idleness The reaction in Americans has been marked, and has closely followed the downward move­ment in Wall Street. Gilt-edged stocks are again lower.
Consols.

After the sharp recovery in the gilt-edged market last week end, first-class securities have again gone back somewhat. This is largely attributed to the fill in the foreign exchanges, and the slightly less favourable monetary posi­tion. Consols are dull at 86 & 5/16 for cash and 86 5/8 xd for the account
Foreign Bonds.

With the exception of Turkish Unified, which have received some support, late national stocks show a weak tendency, in sympathy with some of the Continental hour sea. Russians, after their recent spell of activity, have fallen out of favour, and the scrip yesterday gave away 3/8 to 5 3/8, and the Fours | to ' 7 |. They close to-n;ght at 5 1/4 discount and 77 1/2. Japanese bonds were cheer full on the statement of President Roosevelt regarding the treatment of Japanese in San Francisco, but yesterday there was an easing off, two or three of the series dropping | They are again lower today.
Homo Rails.

During the first part of the week home ra:lway shares were active, and in several cases prices rise appreciably. The dulness of the gilt-edged section has since cast some gloom over the market and the influence of the forthcoming settlement is also being felt. The advance in prices recorded during the part fortnight has brought about some profit-taking and with the exception of blight rises in Gres' Western Ordinary and South Eastern and South Western Deferred the movements and generally adverse. York Deferred, after being a good market previously, fell 1/4 to 45. There has again been some selling of home railway shares to day. York Deferred are 3/8 lower, a Great Westerns have dropped 3/4.
Americans.

The heavy money rates prevailing in New York, coupled with uncertainty with regard to the Presidential message, restricted business in the American market for some time, but when the text of the message was published, the tone became very favourable. The bullish mood was also strengthened by the promise made by Mr. Shaw, the Secretary of the Treasury, to anticipate 12,000,000 dollars of January dividends, and active share dealings became the order of the day. Later yesterday afternoon there was some falling way from the best levels, the weakness if Wall Street being an adverse factor. Union Pacific weakened considerably, and fell away from 193 3/4 to 192 1/4. New York Central, which on Wednesday gained 2 1/4 on the report that the shares were to be placed on a higher divi­dend basis, relapsed 3/4 to 139 1/2.
To day the American railway market has been weak Union Pacifics have given away 2 1/4, New York Central 2 1/2 and Chesapeake 1 1/8. Egyptians

The Egyptian market continues to exhibit a firm tone, and there is a fairly good business being done in the better class shares. In the main quotations show a steady advance in an upward direction, and the prospers for the future are very satisfactory.

Egyptian Estates have been much in demand, and have been as high as 2 5/8. Yesterday the eased off, and closed at 2 1/2 They are quoted to-night at 2 1/2 as compared with 2 7/16 last Friday. The Deferred are steady at 191 National Bank of Egypt have also been a good

marked and advanced to 28 1/4 bid, but last night were easier at 28 3/16 They close today 28 3/8. Agricultural Bank of Egypt are at 9 18/19, and the 3 1/2 per cent Debentures are firmer at 89. Delta Land and Investment, after remain­ing steady at about 4 1/2, came into strong de­mand yesterday,, and rose rapidly to 5 bid, at which price they close to day. Delta Preference Bearer have been better at 12 7/8, but are rather weaker at 12 3/5.

There is little new to say about the issue of the Sidi Salem Estates of Egypt. As yet there does not appear to be much demand for the shares. Lind and General Treat are a fraction better on the dividend of 1s 6d. and leave off at 5s. premium. Daira Sanieh show no change on the week at 17 17/16, the Deferred at 99. Union Fonciere are about the same at 6 1/2 and Land Bank at 8g. Corporation of Western Egypt are steady at & premium, and Salt and Soda and ,Egyptian Markets close at 25s. 6d. and 30s. respectively. Khedivial Mail Ordinary are sellers at 2 1/16.
Mining.

The Government's announcement that the Letters Patent of the new Transvaal Constitu­tion would be proclaimed next week caused some show of activity in the mining market, hot business is very restricted. Paris is a dull factor, and the poor Bank return yesterday did not help matters, while the demand is restric­ted by the approach of the settlement. Yes­terday Kaffirs opened firm, but as the day wore on they again relapsed into, a condition of listlessness. To night Rand Mines are quoted 5 and East Rands 3 3/4.
In the Rhodesian section Chartered are weak at 12.

Egyptian mining shares are idle, at d there is not a single movement to report. For some reason, the public leave this section severely alone. Nile Valleys are at 4s., and Sudan Gold Fields are unchanged at 3/8.

div.head: A Trade Union Secretary
div.p: Going into a Decline.
Depressed; Lifeless; Exhausted;
Racked by Persistent Coughs.
Health and Energy Regained, with Ample Strength for Work. Cured by the Worker's Friend,
Dr. Williams' Pink Pills.

Mr. John Thompson is the energetic and popular secretary io Liverpool of an important trade union, and when be consented to state his personal experience for publication his kindly motive was exploited by the following remarks:—

"As I go to work each morning I pass dozens of fellow-workers who plainly are ill. Any one could tell that they are in the grip of disease, and I would be glad to do them the good turn that a friend once did me. When I had looked on myse'f as a 'goner' beyond human aid a friend advised me to take Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People, and they saved my life; bo I advise every man who earns his daily bread to keep these pills handy."
Mr. Thompson, who is a skilled joiner, living at 4Q, Corney-st., 8mithdown-rd., Liverpool, continued:— *

"My illoes8 began with a depressed feeling ; a kind of washed out-ever-tired sensation hnng over me. I felt lifeless and drowt-y ; yet sleep, when I went to ted, never came to me. This, was followed by severe ohest pains, atd at last a terribly hard congh that would attack me suddenly if I walked at a (pick pace or went op stairs. This cough racked me to pieces, and made my chest terribly raw. When the winter mornings came and I went into the cold air neighbours around would, hear me ooaghing as though my lucgs were in shreds. I felt myself that I could not last. No one held oat hope, and doctors, although thfy did their best, seemed unable to give me just tho medicine my illness required. I was Bil king fast. I tried to keep op my strength, bat I had a most wretohed feeling in my stomach, and for at least two honrs alter every meal I felt that food wonld be rejected. 8o I began to loathe food, and my appetite dwindltd away. I became a stooping, weak-backed, pale, consumptive- looking o* eat are of whom everybody remarked 'He is in a deoline.' My sleep was brokeu by frightful dream', and many hoars I lay awake bathed in weakening perspirations. For days together I cou'd not move owing to nervous headaches. My cough bad now become so bad that every fit prostrated me. Nervous, easily exoited and Hurried, I had to remain away f urn work. I looked haggard, while my flesh had fallen away greatly.
"A fellow-workman, who had groat faith in 1 Dr. Williams' Pink Pills fur Pale People earn­estly begged me to try them. 'You may not be too far gone for them to do you good," said he.

I sleep well, and wake np ready to tackle a hard day's work. I feel wonderfully restored, , more active than for many years, a» d oan do a day's work without being 'done.' div.head: NOTICE.
div.p: Sale of Ivory Rubber.

It is notified for general information that the Assistant Secretary, Stores Section will Ball by Public Auction at the Beit El Aipkna, Otndurmsn,on Monday 16th December 1906 at IQ am. punctually, the following approximate quantities of ivory, rubber, etc.
Rottles
(The ivory will be sold in suitable lots at the rate of so much per kantar.

(Immature ivory acquired under section 17 of|tbe ordinance for the preservation of wild animals and birds 1903 is sold under condition that same is not resold in the Sudan and must but exported ex Sudan within one month from date of purchase and a permit for same will be issued at the time of purchase.

Ten per cent. of the value must be paid by the purchaser at the conclusion of the auction and the balance within 5 days from the above date, after which period it will remain at pur- chaser's risk and be subject -to a demurrage charge of 100 milliemes per each kantar per diem until whole stock is removed.
None of the articles. sold can be removed before the whole of the purchase money has been paid.
The payments will be in cash and no cheques will be accepted.
The Government does not bind itself to accept the highest or any offer.
(Signed) M. Coutts, Kaim.
Assistant Secretary,
States Section.
Khartoum, 29th November, 1906.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: L'animation persiste sur les Zariffa et Ritz, Ceux ci débutent à 1 17/39, et atteignent 1 93/89 pour finir à 1 19/32 acheteurs. Les Zariffa ouvrent 4 4 1/4 pour terminer ache­teurs à oe prix ; la part de fondateur, après avoir atteint 24-25, clôture à 23.
Beaucoup d'aff tires également en National Bank, Cassa di Sconto, Nungovich Hotels, Estâtes, Urbaine et Comptoir.

La baisse est éuorme et générale, on dirait pretque une panique. Qi'on en juge plutôt: l'AgriooIe perd 5/32 à 9 9/16, la National Bank 5/B à 28 1/4, la Béhéra 2 livres 4 40, la Cassa di Soonto 4 fr. à 969 l'anoienne et 260 vendeurs la nouvelle, les Nungovich 1 livre 7/16 4 21 7/16, la Nile Land 5/8 4 18 1/4, la part de fondateur Comptoir 1/2 livre 4 62, et l'Union Fonoière prèi de 3/16 à 6 9/32.

Eu baisse également les Markets de £0 4 29/3, la Bière d'Alexandrie de 207 4 206 la Privilégiée et de 120 4 118 vendeart la Divi­dende, la Sait & Soda de 23/3 4 23, les Lots Turcs de 153 4 152, la Banque d'Athènes de 138 4 136 1/4, la Delta Land de 4 5/8 4 4 1/2. l'Ordinary Khédivial Mail de 40/3» 4 40 ven­deurs, l'Investmeat de 1 1/2 4 1 13/32, les Estâtes de 2 1/2 4 2 7/16, l'aotion Comptoir de 7 1/2 4 7 3/8, le Crédit Franoo-Egyptien de 6 1/4 4 6 3/16 et U Land Bank de 8 3/4 485/8.
Il n'y a en hausse, d'ailleurs l'insignifiante, que les Privilégiées Tramways d'Alexandrie de913 4 215 acheteurs, et les Privilégiées Bière du Caire de 134 4 135.
Le Trust est ferme 4 1 21/32 acheteurs, l'Urbaine 4 7 3/4-13/15 et les Splendid Hotels 4 4 1/4 acheteurs.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.
